title: Boeuf Bourguignon (Small Pot)
description: A rich, slow-braised French classic featuring tender beef simmered in red wine, aromatics and mushrooms until melt-in-your-mouth. Concentrated flavors develop through searing, deglazing and gentle oven braising for an intensely savory, comforting stew.

ingredients.display_name: beef chuck, trimmed and cut into 1 1/2-inch cubes
yellow onion, medium, peeled and sliced into 1/2-inch wedges
carrots, peeled and cut on bias into 1/2-inch pieces
dry red wine (burgundy, pinot noir or similar)
button mushrooms, halved or quartered depending on size
cornstarch (or additional flour) mixed with water for slurry (optional to thicken)
ingredients.notes: mix with 1 tbsp cold water if needed

steps.text: Preheat oven to 325°F (160°C). Pat beef dry, season with half the salt and pepper, then dust lightly with flour. This helps with browning and thickening.

Heat a heavy small Dutch oven or oven-safe pot over medium-high heat. Add olive oil and sear beef in batches without crowding until deeply browned on all sides; transfer browned pieces to a bowl between batches.
Reduce heat to medium, add bacon and cook until fat renders and edges are crisp; remove most of the rendered fat leaving about 1 tablespoon in the pot.
Add sliced onion and carrots to the pot and sauté until softened and lightly caramelized, about 6–8 minutes. Stir in minced garlic and tomato paste and cook 1 minute to bloom flavors.
Return beef and any accumulated juices to the pot. Pour in red wine to deglaze, scraping up browned bits from the bottom; bring to a simmer and reduce by about one-third, approximately 8–10 minutes.
Add hot beef stock, thyme sprigs and bay leaves. The liquid should almost cover the meat. Bring to a gentle simmer on the stovetop.
Cover the pot and transfer to the preheated oven. Braise until beef is very tender and the sauce is concentrated, about 2 hours (120 minutes).
While braise is finishing, heat a skillet over medium-high heat with butter. Sauté mushrooms until browned and liquid evaporates, about 6–8 minutes; set aside.

When braise is done, remove pot from oven. Skim excess fat from the surface, discard thyme stems and bay leaves. If sauce needs thickening, simmer uncovered on stovetop and/or stir in slurry until desired consistency is reached (2–4 minutes).
Stir sautéed mushrooms back into the stew and adjust seasoning with remaining salt and pepper. Garnish with chopped parsley and serve hot with mashed potatoes, buttered noodles or crusty bread.
